awd_titl_txt: On Heavier Chalcogen (Se and Te) Interfacial Chemistry and Charge Transfer in Monolayer-Protected Metal Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
Metal nanoparticles are metal particles of very small (nanometer scale) dimensions.  They possess novel chemical and physical properties that are very different from those of large particles or bulk metals.  Dr. YuYe Tong of Georgetown University and Dr. Thomas Allison at the National Institute of Standards and Technology conduct research to gain a better understanding of the structural parameters that govern the properties of metal nanoparticles.  The long-term goal is to harness the novel properties of nanoparticles for practical applications (such as electronic or optical devices, biomedical diagnosis, and drug delivery).   This project provides interdisciplinary research opportunities to students, training them in the use of the state-of-the-art instruments for studying nanoparticles.  Through Georgetown University's partnership with the Cesar Chavez Public Charter Schools in Southeast Washington DC, which have very high population of students of underrepresented groups or from low-income families, Dr. Tong participates in a project to help develop new chemistry curricula for local charter schools.  This project serves as a springboard to attract more women and underrepresented students to STEM fields.

Dr. Tong and Dr. Allison explore the use of heavier chalcogen (Se and Te) as alternative anchoring elements to the prevailingly used sulfur for attaching organic molecular wires to metal surfaces.  Using a combination of experimental techniques and Density Functional Theory (DFT) computations, they aim to gain a better mechanistic understanding of the metal-chalcogenolate interfacial chemistry and its ramifications on charge transfer/transport in single monolayer-protected nanoparticle (MPN) and MPN assemblies.  Specifically, this research entails: 1) the synthesis of different sizes (1 to 5 nm) of nanoparticles of different metal elements (Au, Ag, Cu, Pt, and Pd), which are protected with ligands of different organic backbones (alkyl and aryl), alkyl chain lengths (C6, C8, and C12), and anchoring chalcogen elements (Se and Te); 2) the characterization of the afore-synthesized MPNs by in situ electrochemical (EC) spectroscopic (NMR/IR/Raman) techniques and ex situ X-ray photoemission spectroscopy; and 3) comparative mechanistic investigations of charge transfer through a single MPN and MPN assemblies using EC scanning tunneling microscopy and traditional EC measurements.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the funding period of the NSF Award CHE-1413429 entitled ?On Heavier Chalcogen (Se and Te) Interfacial Chemistry and Charge Transfer in Monolayer-Protected Metal Nanoparticles?, research efforts were geared toward achieving two primary objectives: (1) a systematic extension from the wells studied Au?thiolate interfacial chemistry to the much less studied Au?selenolate/?tellurolate interfacial chemistry and by which to a more general metal?chalcogenolate interfacial chemistry and (2) better understanding of the ramifications of the metal?chalcogenolate interfacial chemistry on charge transfer/transport (CT) in the associated monolayer-protected metal nanoparticles (MPN) assemblies. These research efforts have led us to make some key progresses in two fronts: the synthesis of organochalcogenolate-stabilized metal (gold, silver and platinum) nanoparticles (NPs) or clusters and developing their physical characterization methods.

In the synthesis of organochalcogenolate-stabilized metal (e.g. gold, silver and platinum) nanoparticles (NPs) or clusters, practical challenges have been that the literature-available syntheses usually have complicated workup procedures and the reported results are frequently hard to reproduce. As such, we have made deliberated effort to develop simpler, more robust and reproducible metal NP or cluster syntheses. More specifically, we have developed (1) a straightforward one-pot, robust, and highly reproducible synthesis of Au25(SR)18 that is much simpler than the current prevailing synthetic procedures and also produces higher yield, (2) an improved synthetic route for synthesizing Pt1Au24(SR)18 bimetallic clusters with higher yield and purity compared to those reported in the literature, (3) synthetic procedures that can produce reproducibly highly homogeneous (<7% standard deviation) and stable (>6 months shelf live) alkanethiolate-stabilized Ag NPs, and (4) an adapted synthesis of stable, water-soluble and homogeneous silver clusters (~Ag25) stabilized by 3-mercaptobenzoic acid.

In the development of physical methods to characterize the synthesized metal NPs or clusters, we have developed an in situ electrochemical C-13 NMR method, which combines the electrochemistry of organo-ligand-stabilized Au NPs with C-13 NMR spectroscopy, that enables measuring energy-level alignment at a metal?molecule interface between the Fermi level of the metal and the frontier orbitals of the stabilizing ligand and access to both occupied and unoccupied states at the metal-ligand interface.  We have also demonstrated that high-resolution solution C-13 NMR can be used as a highly sensitive and quantitative spectroscopic method to unravel structural and interfacial chemistry of atomic precise Au clusters. For instance, for diamagnetic anion (Au25SR18)? clusters, C-13 chemical shift of the tail methyl group can sense the structural difference between the Ausurface-S-Ausurface and Aucore-S-Ausurface interfacial bonding geometries, where Ausurface and Aucore are respectively one of the 12 Au atoms in the cluster?s surface shell and of the 12 Au atoms in the cluster?s core. For the paramagnetic neutral (Au25SR18)0, the C-13 spectra showed for the first time that the unpaired electron is localized dominantly at the 6 Ausurface-S-Ausurface bonding structure. Finally, using the grant-funded scanning probe microscope, we have developed a novel versatile and robust surface-poison-resisting scanning amperometric proton microscopy (SAPM). The SAPM measures the current of hydrogen evolution reaction 2H+ + 2e? ?> H2 that is proportional to the concentration of proton, i.e., pH value, at the tip of a Pt ultramicroelectrode (~600 nm). A current decrease of 1.75 pA corresponds to a rate of 1.1 x 107 H+/s (or 1.81 x 10-17 mol H+/s) for a cytochrome c enabled proton pumping was measured, demonstrating the method?s potential to study proton-coupled electron or polypeptide transfer reactions that are prevailing in many key biological processes.

As to the broad impact activities, we have helped develop new teaching modules for a science course at Czar Chavez High School in Washington DC that introduce concepts of alternative energies within the framework of satisfying the criteria of the Next Generation Science Standards. These teaching modules were used in the course in Spring 2015. Additionally, the project has served as a conduit for 14 undergraduate students and 9 high school students to deepen their chemistry knowledge and build up their independent research skills set via carrying out authentic research in the PI?s lab, in addition to the expected training of graduate students and post-doctoral fellows.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2019
Modified by: Yuye J Tong
